added_lines: search_opts = self.get_filters() **search_opts) def get_filters(self): filters = {} filter_field = self.table.get_filter_field() filter_action = self.table._meta._filter_action if filter_action.is_api_filter(filter_field): filter_string = self.table.get_filter_string().strip() if filter_field and filter_string: if filter_field == 'admin_state_up': if _("up") == filter_string.lower(): filters['admin_state_up'] = True elif _("down") == filter_string.lower(): filters['admin_state_up'] = False if filter_field not in filters: filters[filter_field] = filter_string return filters

commit_message:
Remove router rules extension

Router rules is a horizon extension provided by Big Switch Networks.
As part of the horizon-vendor-split work, we drop the extension from
upstream horizon.
It is now available as a separate plugin at
https://github.com/bigswitch/horizon-bsn

Change-Id: I439f6f87057547f9bc0fbb7089d37b4e9603b1c1
Partially-implements: blueprint horizon-vendor-split

commit_message:
Fix the loss of JSON types when using multipart/form-data

To pass a binary blob in a POST request, browser sets the header
'Content-Type: multipart/form-data', which in turn causes all form
fields' values to be passed as strings. Circumvent this by storing
original field values as a JSON string on client-side and decoding it
on server-side. As a result the setting HORIZON_IMAGES_UPLOAD_MODE =
'legacy' will start working together with Glance V2.

Closes-Bug: #1613703
Change-Id: I53a8fbba15e4c3c6c17d6ef1ffe701634efda149

commit_message:
Support project column in admin view of NG images

This adds the project name column to ng images, which
is required in order to support an admin view for images.

In addition the hz-property directive could not handle
promises, which is required for doing things like
looking up the project name from the project id.
This adds limited support for that.

Change-Id: I0bb3782a23cf6ddff249459089b96a532aa8a0d8
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-images-table

commit_message:
Add unit tests to edit-image to improve coverage

This test adds unit tests that improve coverage and describe necessary code paths.

Change-Id: I93eb79a3b9d09cba777d6e1ac84196f8584c70dd
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-images-table
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/58/356658/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: var service, $scope, $q, deferred, testImage, $timeout, updateImageDeferred; return callback({ return callback(); updateImage: function() { return updateImageDeferred.promise; imageLoad.resolve({data: {id: 1, name: 'Test'}}); updateImageDeferred = $q.defer(); describe('submit', function() { beforeEach(function() { var image = {id: 1, name: 'Original'}; spyOn(glanceAPI, 'updateImage').and.callThrough(); spyOn(wizardModalService, 'modal').and.callThrough(); service.initScope($scope); service.perform(image); $timeout.flush(); }); it('passes the image from the model to updateImage', function() { var modalArgs = wizardModalService.modal.calls.argsFor(0)[0]; modalArgs.submit(); updateImageDeferred.resolve(); $timeout.flush(); expect(glanceAPI.updateImage.calls.argsFor(0)[0]).toEqual({id: 1, name: 'Test'}); }); it('returns a failed result if API call fails', function() { var modalArgs = wizardModalService.modal.calls.argsFor(0)[0]; var result = modalArgs.submit(); updateImageDeferred.reject(); result.then(function err(data) { expect(data.failed.length).toBe(1); }); $timeout.flush(); }); it('updates metadata on event', function() { $scope.$emit('horizon.app.core.images.IMAGE_METADATA_CHANGED', {i_am: 'metadata'}); $scope.$apply(); spyOn(metadataService, 'editMetadata').and.callThrough(); var modalArgs = wizardModalService.modal.calls.argsFor(0)[0]; modalArgs.submit(); expect(metadataService.editMetadata.calls.argsFor(0)[2]).toEqual({i_am: 'metadata'}); }); });
deleted_lines: callback({ callback(); updateImage: function(image) { return { then: function(callback) { callback({data: image}); } }; imageLoad.resolve({data: testImage}); var service, $scope, $q, deferred, testImage, $timeout;

'}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2016-04-27 15:36:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/483d27b1ee32d9e7b41535c2074fe9d22abaa364', 'message': "Allow to upload the image directly to Glance service

Since large Glance images even temporarily stored on dashboard side tend to fill up Web Server filesystem, it is desirable to route image payload directly to Glance service (which usually streams it to storage backend, which in turn has plenty of space).

To make it possible we need to trick Django into thinking that a file
was selected inside FileInput, while its contents are not actually
transferred to Django server. Then, once image is created client-side
code needs to know the exact url the image payload needs to be
transferred to. Both tasks are solved via using ExternalFileField /
ExternalUploadMeta classes which allow to work around the usual Django
form processing workflow with minimal changes to CreateImage form
business logic.

The client-side code relies on CORS being enabled for Glance service
(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard) and restart glance-api process.

A progress bar is implemented to track the progress of a file upload,
in case a really huge image is transferred.

The new machinery could be easily switched on/off with a single
setting `HORIZON_IMAGES_DIRECT_UPLOAD`.

Closes-Bug: #1403129
Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I01d02f75268186b43066df6fd966aa01c08e01d7

(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard) and restart glance-api process.

A progress bar is implemented to track the progress of a file upload,
in case a really huge image is transferred.

The new machinery could be easily switched on/off with a single
setting `HORIZON_IMAGES_DIRECT_UPLOAD`.

Closes-Bug: #1403129
Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I01d02f75268186b43066df6fd966aa01c08e01d7
"}, {'number': 24, 'created': '2016-05-17 10:17:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/6e6c7d421b496640f166a685fbdb6200146a0e14', 'message': "Allow to upload the image directly to Glance service

Since large Glance images even temporarily stored on dashboard side
tend to fill up Web Server filesystem, it is desirable to route image
payload directly to Glance service (which usually streams it to
storage backend, which in turn has plenty of space).

To make it possible we need to trick Django into thinking that a file
was selected inside FileInput, while its contents are not actually
transferred to Django server. Then, once image is created client-side
code needs to know the exact url the image payload needs to be
transferred to. Both tasks are solved via using ExternalFileField /
ExternalUploadMeta classes which allow to work around the usual Django
form processing workflow with minimal changes to CreateImage form
business logic.

The client-side code relies on CORS being enabled for Glance service
(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard) and restart glance-api process.

A progress bar is implemented to track the progress of a file upload,
in case a really huge image is transferred.

The new machinery could be easily switched on/off with a single
setting `HORIZON_IMAGES_DIRECT_UPLOAD`.

Closes-Bug: #1403129
Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I01d02f75268186b43066df6fd966aa01c08e01d7

tend to fill up Web Server filesystem, it is desirable to route image
payload directly to Glance service (which usually streams it to
storage backend, which in turn has plenty of space).

To make it possible we need to trick Django into thinking that a file
was selected inside FileInput, while its contents are not actually
transferred to Django server. Then, once image is created client-side
code needs to know the exact url the image payload needs to be
transferred to. Both tasks are solved via using ExternalFileField /
ExternalUploadMeta classes which allow to work around the usual Django
form processing workflow with minimal changes to CreateImage form
business logic.

The client-side code relies on CORS being enabled for Glance service
(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard) and restart glance-api process.

A progress bar is implemented to track the progress of a file upload,
in case a really huge image is transferred.

The new machinery could be easily switched on/off with a single
setting `HORIZON_IMAGES_UPLOAD_MODE` set to 'direct' / 'legacy'.

Related-Bug: #1467890
Closes-Bug: #1403129
Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I01d02f75268186b43066df6fd966aa01c08e01d7

commit_message:
[Django] Allow to upload the image directly to Glance service

Since large Glance images even temporarily stored on dashboard side
tend to fill up Web Server filesystem, it is desirable to route image
payload directly to Glance service (which usually streams it to
storage backend, which in turn has plenty of space).

To make it possible we need to trick Django into thinking that a file
was selected inside FileInput, while its contents are not actually
transferred to Django server. Then, once image is created client-side
code needs to know the exact url the image payload needs to be
transferred to. Both tasks are solved via using ExternalFileField /
ExternalUploadMeta classes which allow to work around the usual Django
form processing workflow with minimal changes to CreateImage form
business logic.

The client-side code relies on CORS being enabled for Glance service
(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard) and restart glance-api process.

A progress bar is implemented to track the progress of a file upload,
in case a really huge image is transferred.

The new machinery could be easily switched on/off with a single
setting `HORIZON_IMAGES_UPLOAD_MODE` set to 'direct' / 'legacy'.

Related-Bug: #1467890
Closes-Bug: #1403129
Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I01d02f75268186b43066df6fd966aa01c08e01d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/34/230434/28 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six from django.forms.forms import DeclarativeFieldsMetaclass class AsynchronousFileField(forms.FileField): def clean(self, data, initial=None): data = super(AsynchronousFileField, self).clean(data, initial) return data class AsynchronousFileInput(forms.FileInput): needs_multipart_form = False class AsyncUploadMeta(DeclarativeFieldsMetaclass): def __new__(mcs, name, bases, attrs): def get_double_name(name): suffix = '__hidden' slen = len(suffix) return name[:-slen] if name.endswith(suffix) else name + suffix def make_clean_method(field_name): def _clean_method(self): value = self.cleaned_data[field_name] if value: self.cleaned_data[get_double_name(field_name)] = value return value return _clean_method new_attrs = {} for attr_name, attr in attrs.items(): new_attrs[attr_name] = attr if isinstance(attr, AsynchronousFileField): hidden_field = forms.CharField(widget=forms.HiddenInput, required=False) hidden_field.creation_counter = attr.creation_counter + 1000 new_attr_name = get_double_name(attr_name) new_attrs[new_attr_name] = hidden_field meth_name = 'clean_' + new_attr_name new_attrs[meth_name] = make_clean_method(new_attr_name) return super(AsyncUploadMeta, mcs).__new__(mcs, name, bases, new_attrs) class CreateImageForm(six.with_metaclass(AsyncUploadMeta, forms.SelfHandlingForm)): image_file = AsynchronousFileField( label=_("Image File"), help_text=_("A local image to upload."), widget=AsynchronousFileInput(attrs={ 'class': 'switched', 'data-switch-on': 'source', 'data-source-file': _('Image File'), 'ng-model': 'imageFile', 'ng-change': 'ctrl.selectImageFormat(imageFile.name)', 'image-file-on-change': None}), required=False) image_endpoint = api.base.url_for(request, 'image') self.fields['image_file'].widget.attrs.update({ 'data-async-upload': "%s/v1/images/" % image_endpoint }) async_upload = False if (policy.check((("image", "upload_image"),), request) and data.get('image_file', None)): async_upload = True if async_upload: image.async_upload_id = image.id
deleted_lines: class CreateImageForm(forms.SelfHandlingForm): image_file = forms.FileField(label=_("Image File"), help_text=_("A local image to upload."), widget=forms.FileInput(attrs={ 'class': 'switched', 'data-switch-on': 'source', 'data-source-file': _('Image File'), 'ng-model': 'imageFile', 'ng-change': 'ctrl.selectImageFormat(imageFile.name)', 'image-file-on-change': None}), required=False) if (settings.HORIZON_IMAGES_ALLOW_UPLOAD and policy.check((("image", "upload_image"),), request) and data.get('image_file', None)): meta['data'] = self.files['image_file']

commit_message:
Add more Nova API features for NG Instances

This patch adds more Nova API features for instances.  It establishes
several new proxy APIs and provides the various JavaScript libraries for
accessing those APIs as well.

Change-Id: I016be1d0598faf78b1fb02f4d0768efdaf6cb7bf
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-instances-table
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/49/344949/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from collections import OrderedDict from horizon import exceptions as hz_exceptions import six @urls.register class Snapshots(generic.View): """API for nova keypairs. """ url_regex = r'nova/snapshots/$' @rest_utils.ajax(data_required=True) def post(self, request): instance_id = request.DATA['instance_id'] result = api.nova.snapshot_create(request, instance_id=instance_id, name=request.DATA['name']) return result class ServerActions(generic.View): """API over all server actions. """ url_regex = r'nova/servers/(?P<server_id>[^/]+)/actions/$' @rest_utils.ajax() def get(self, request, server_id): """Get a list of server actions. The listing result is an object with property "items". Each item is an action taken against the given server. Example GET: http://localhost/api/nova/servers/abcd/actions/ """ actions = api.nova.instance_action_list(request, server_id) return {'items': [s.to_dict() for s in actions]} @urls.register class SecurityGroups(generic.View): """API over all server volumes. """ url_regex = r'nova/servers/(?P<server_id>[^/]+)/security-groups/$' @rest_utils.ajax() def get(self, request, server_id): """Get a list of server security groups. The listing result is an object with property "items". Each item is security group associated with this server. Example GET: http://localhost/api/nova/servers/abcd/security-groups/ """ groups = api.network.server_security_groups(request, server_id) return {'items': [s.to_dict() for s in groups]} @urls.register class Volumes(generic.View): """API over all server volumes. """ url_regex = r'nova/servers/(?P<server_id>[^/]+)/volumes/$' @rest_utils.ajax() def get(self, request, server_id): """Get a list of server volumes. The listing result is an object with property "items". Each item is an action taken against the given server. Example GET: http://localhost/api/nova/servers/abcd/volumes/ """ volumes = api.nova.instance_volumes_list(request, server_id) return {'items': [s.to_dict() for s in volumes]} @urls.register class RemoteConsoleInfo(generic.View): """API for remote console information. """ url_regex = r'nova/servers/(?P<server_id>[^/]+)/console-info/$' @rest_utils.ajax() def post(self, request, server_id): """Get a list of lines of console output. The listing result is an object with property "items". Each item is a line of output from the server. Example GET: http://localhost/api/nova/servers/abcd/console-output/ """ console_type = request.DATA.get('console_type', 'AUTO') CONSOLES = OrderedDict([('VNC', api.nova.server_vnc_console), ('SPICE', api.nova.server_spice_console), ('RDP', api.nova.server_rdp_console), ('SERIAL', api.nova.server_serial_console)]) """Get a tuple of console url and console type.""" if console_type == 'AUTO': check_consoles = CONSOLES else: try: check_consoles = {console_type: CONSOLES[console_type]} except KeyError: msg = _('Console type "%s" not supported.') % console_type raise hz_exceptions.NotAvailable(msg) # Ugly workaround due novaclient API change from 2.17 to 2.18. try: httpnotimplemented = exceptions.HttpNotImplemented except AttributeError: httpnotimplemented = exceptions.HTTPNotImplemented for con_type, api_call in six.iteritems(check_consoles): try: console = api_call(request, server_id) # If not supported, don't log it to avoid lot of errors in case # of AUTO. except httpnotimplemented: continue except Exception: continue if con_type == 'SERIAL': console_url = console.url else: console_url = "%s&%s(%s)" % ( console.url, utils_http.urlencode({'title': _("Console")}), server_id) return {"type": con_type, "url": console_url} raise hz_exceptions.NotAvailable(_('No available console found.')) @urls.register class ConsoleOutput(generic.View): """API for console output. """ url_regex = r'nova/servers/(?P<server_id>[^/]+)/console-output/$' @rest_utils.ajax() def post(self, request, server_id): """Get a list of lines of console output. The listing result is an object with property "items". Each item is a line of output from the server. Example GET: http://localhost/api/nova/servers/abcd/console-output/ """ log_length = request.DATA.get('length', 100) console_lines = api.nova.server_console_output(request, server_id, tail_length=log_length) return {"lines": [x for x in console_lines.split('\n')]} @urls.register 'config_drive' @rest_utils.ajax(data_required=True) def post(self, request, server_id): """Perform a change to a server """ operation = request.DATA.get('operation', 'none') if operation == 'stop': return api.nova.server_stop(request, server_id) elif operation == 'start': return api.nova.server_start(request, server_id) elif operation == 'pause': return api.nova.server_pause(request, server_id) elif operation == 'unpause': return api.nova.server_unpause(request, server_id) elif operation == 'suspend': return api.nova.server_suspend(request, server_id) elif operation == 'resume': return api.nova.server_resume(request, server_id) elif operation == 'hard_reboot': return api.nova.server_reboot(request, server_id, False) elif operation == 'soft_reboot': return api.nova.server_reboot(request, server_id, True) @rest_utils.ajax() def delete(self, request, server_id): api.nova.server_delete(request, server_id)

commit_message:
Pre-test hook for integration tests/deprecated

We want to allow for integration tests to test deprecated panels.  This
means that we need to override the configurations provided by the panels
and force a 'legacy' setting.

On the Infra side, we need to pass in an environment variable that tells this
override to be enabled.

Depends-On: I20232ef16ae60a7151e267b506af471ebfed2f7f
Change-Id: If5a3e273098aa726e12f9076c0273a5afaf233d2
Partially-Implements: blueprint test-deprecated-features

added_lines: # This file is to be included for configuring integration tests when # wanting to only test legacy panels. Since 'local' modules are evaluated # after core modules, these configurations will override the panel settings. HORIZON_CONFIG["images_panel"] = "legacy" HORIZON_CONFIG["flavors_panel"] = "legacy"

commit_message:
[NG] Enhance Create Image workflow with upload tracking

Create Image service uses $scope captured in a closure var `scope` to
pass the upload progress of the local image file to Glance service
into modal form controller.

Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I98711e6a5e59c91ef71a726a6ff094767d421ef7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/57/317457/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ctrl.uploadProgress = 0; var watchUploadProgress = $scope.$on(events.IMAGE_UPLOAD_PROGRESS, watchImageUpload); watchUploadProgress(); function watchImageUpload(event, progress) { ctrl.uploadProgress = progress; }

commit_message:
Horizon Radio Buttons are now themeable.

Horizon radio buttons were using the standard browser radio buttons.
The default radio buttons have been altered to allow for a highly
customized experience through the use of CSS pseudo elements and
Icon Fonts. This allows the color, size, and unselected and selected
states of the checkbox to be altered. The 'default' theme uses the
standard Font Awesome radio button icons. The 'material' theme uses
the Material Design radio buttons. It was noted, during this refactor,
that there was an error in the _themable_checkbox template. This has
been fixed.

Change-Id: I1ca2e39e893b45adddf513c0dcb2670b2876594f
Partially-Implements: blueprint horizon-theme-css-reorg

the registry for later use by the table.

Change-Id: Ibdb51157a540a2c23d5f5bb324d37a918c2e51ab
Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson tyr@hpe.com
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-images-table
'}]
commit_message:
hz-images have transitional states defined

Using the transitional-states framework defined in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/346174
The images generic panel now defines a call-back method for determining
if an image is in a transitional state.  Thid call-back is registered in
the registry for later use by the table.

Change-Id: Ibdb51157a540a2c23d5f5bb324d37a918c2e51ab
Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson tyr@hpe.com
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-images-table
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/10/346210/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .setIsInTransition(imagesService.isInTransition) priority: 1, isInTransitionFunc: imagesService.isInTransition

subject: [NG] Support local file upload in Create Image workflow
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-17 13:20:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/1737be9c356d3590727bec115c6b25a875208bc7', 'message': '[WIP] Glance Create Image with file upload

Change-Id: I5d842d614c16d3250380ea1dc1c6e0289d206fb5
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-05-17 17:15:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/3d4ecab8be9ca888104f8963c2d019d3a06bfd7f', 'message': "Support local file upload in NG Create Image workflow

Where '/api/glance/images' POST call to Horizon REST API wrappers
previously returned the final image object that Glance just created,
now there are two possibilities.

* When Create Image form Source Type is set to URL, then everything is
  going as before.
* When Source Type is set to File, then just a file name instead of an
  actual Blob is sent to '/api/glance/images', then the Glance Image
  is queued for creation and Horizon web-server responds with an Image
  object which has 2 additional attributes: 'uploadUrl' and
  'tokenId'. The uploadUrl tells the location for the subsequent CORS
  request, while token id is passed as a header in that request, so
  Keystone would let it in. CORS upload is started immeditely as Image
  is queued for creation (first promise is resolved) and returns the
  second promise, which is resolved once the upload finishes. The
  modal form hangs until second promise resolves to indicate that
  upload is in progress. Upload progress notification is added in a
  follow-up patch.

TBD: unit tests

DEPLOY NOTES

The client-side code relies on CORS being enabled for Glance service
(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard). Another thing that needs to be done is
uncommenting 'cors.allow_headers' and adding 'X-Requested-With' header
to a list of allowed headers, since ngFileUpload sets this header.

Change-Id: I5d842d614c16d3250380ea1dc1c6e0289d206fb5

"}, {'number': 16, 'created': '2016-06-24 11:53:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/5311cea86ec53c8de3a4a451cc7bc442d32cf02d', 'message': "[NG] Support local file upload in Create Image workflow

Where '/api/glance/images' POST call to Horizon REST API wrappers
previously returned the final image object that Glance just created,
now there are two possibilities.

* When Create Image form Source Type is set to URL, then everything is
  going as before.
* When Source Type is set to File, then just a file name instead of an
  actual Blob is sent to '/api/glance/images', then the Glance Image
  is queued for creation and Horizon web-server responds with an Image
  object which dict() representation has 2 additional keys:
  'upload_url' and 'token_id'. The 'upload_url' tells the location for
  the subsequent CORS request, while 'token_id' is passed as a header
  in that request, so Keystone would let it in. CORS upload is started
  immediately as Image is queued for creation (first promise is
  resolved) and returns the second promise, which is resolved once the
  upload finishes. The modal form hangs until second promise resolves
  to indicate that upload is in progress. Upload progress notification
  is added in a follow-up patch.

DEPLOY NOTES

The client-side code relies on CORS being enabled for Glance service
(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard).

Related-Bug: #1467890
Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I5d842d614c16d3250380ea1dc1c6e0289d206fb5

"}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2016-07-07 15:19:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/0a63dfe399d4f2425d2835ecab2ab0e3bd35c269', 'message': "[NG] Support local file upload in Create Image workflow

First, now there are 2 '/api/glance/images/ API wrapper endpoints for
creating a new image - POST and PUT. The POST endpoint which existed
before now resides at PUT. This was done to support legacy
(i.e. proxied by web-server) file uploads in Angular Create Image,
because Django (which we need to use in that case) doesn't correctly
process PUT request. So, if local file binary payload is added to the
form contents, we send it using POST request.

Second, speaking of '/api/glance/images' PUT request previously known
as POST... Where before the POST call to Horizon REST API wrappers
returned the final image object that Glance just created, now there
are two possibilities for what happens after PUT is sent.

* When Create Image form Source Type is set to URL, then everything is
  going as before.
* When Source Type is set to File, then just a file name instead of an
  actual Blob is sent to '/api/glance/images', then the Glance Image
  is queued for creation and Horizon web-server responds with an Image
  object which dict() representation has 2 additional keys:
  'upload_url' and 'token_id'. The 'upload_url' tells the location for
  the subsequent CORS request, while 'token_id' is passed as a header
  in that request, so Keystone would let it in. CORS upload is started
  immediately as Image is queued for creation (first promise is
  resolved) and returns the second promise, which is resolved once the
  upload finishes. The modal form hangs until second promise resolves
  to indicate that upload is in progress. Upload progress notification
  is added in a follow-up patch.

DEPLOY NOTES

The client-side code relies on CORS being enabled for Glance service
(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard).

Related-Bug: #1467890
Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I5d842d614c16d3250380ea1dc1c6e0289d206fb5

* When Create Image form Source Type is set to URL, then everything is
  going as before.
* When Source Type is set to File, then just a file name instead of an
  actual Blob is sent to '/api/glance/images', then the Glance Image
  is queued for creation and Horizon web-server responds with an Image
  object which dict() representation has 2 additional keys:
  'upload_url' and 'token_id'. The 'upload_url' tells the location for
  the subsequent CORS request, while 'token_id' is passed as a header
  in that request, so Keystone would let it in. CORS upload is started
  immediately as Image is queued for creation (first promise is
  resolved) and returns the second promise, which is resolved once the
  upload finishes. The modal form hangs until second promise resolves
  to indicate that upload is in progress. Upload progress notification
  is added in a follow-up patch.

DEPLOY NOTES

The client-side code relies on CORS being enabled for Glance service
(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard).

Related-Bug: #1467890
Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I5d842d614c16d3250380ea1dc1c6e0289d206fb5

commit_message:
[NG] Support local file upload in Create Image workflow

First, now there are 2 '/api/glance/images/ API wrapper endpoints for
creating a new image - POST and PUT. The POST endpoint which existed
before now resides at PUT. This was done to support legacy
(i.e. proxied by web-server) file uploads in Angular Create Image,
because Django (which we need to use in that case) doesn't correctly
process PUT request. So, if local file binary payload is added to the
form contents, we send it using POST request.

Second, speaking of '/api/glance/images' PUT request previously known
as POST... Where before the POST call to Horizon REST API wrappers
returned the final image object that Glance just created, now there
are two possibilities for what happens after PUT is sent.

* When Create Image form Source Type is set to URL, then everything is
  going as before.
* When Source Type is set to File, then just a file name instead of an
  actual Blob is sent to '/api/glance/images', then the Glance Image
  is queued for creation and Horizon web-server responds with an Image
  object which dict() representation has 2 additional keys:
  'upload_url' and 'token_id'. The 'upload_url' tells the location for
  the subsequent CORS request, while 'token_id' is passed as a header
  in that request, so Keystone would let it in. CORS upload is started
  immediately as Image is queued for creation (first promise is
  resolved) and returns the second promise, which is resolved once the
  upload finishes. The modal form hangs until second promise resolves
  to indicate that upload is in progress. Upload progress notification
  is added in a follow-up patch.

DEPLOY NOTES

The client-side code relies on CORS being enabled for Glance service
(otherwise browser would forbid the PUT request to a location
different from the one form content came from). In a Devstack setup
you'll need to edit [cors] section of glance-api.conf file, setting
`allowed_origin` setting to the full hostname of the web server (say,
http://<HOST_IP>/dashboard).

Related-Bug: #1467890
Implements blueprint: horizon-glance-large-image-upload
Change-Id: I5d842d614c16d3250380ea1dc1c6e0289d206fb5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/56/317456/24 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if request.DATA.get('image_url'): if request.DATA.get('import_data'): meta['copy_from'] = request.DATA.get('image_url') else: meta['location'] = request.DATA.get('image_url') else: meta['data'] = request.DATA.get('data') image_dict = image.to_dict() if hasattr(image, 'file_transfer_url'): image_dict['uploadUrl'] = image.file_transfer_url image_dict['tokenId'] = request.user.token.id image_dict 'image_url', 'source_type', 'data',
deleted_lines: if request.DATA.get('import_data'): meta['copy_from'] = request.DATA.get('image_url') else: meta['location'] = request.DATA.get('image_url') image.to_dict() 'image_url', 'source_type',

subject: hz-resource-table handles transitional states
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-22 18:59:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/3d28db8cf278a4d66847deb64cf846ef4c179b12', 'message': "hz-resource-table handles transitional states

In the django tables, if a resource goes into a transitional-state
(think building, deleting, shutting-down, ...) the table would highlight
that behavior with 2 changes:
A) the row would be highlighted
B) a barber-pole would show up in the status column

The new-ish registry-based hz-resource-table wasn't making either of
those visual changes.  But now it is!  Hurray for fewer regressions!

Change-Id: Ic84b1eabc2c32e7ba48bf9ce2279f69a4e9a95e0
Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson tyr@hpe.com
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-22 20:17:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/0a6eec3d5faa405bdedc350c55dff8544e567316', 'message': "hz-resource-table handles transitional states

In the django tables, if a resource goes into a transitional-state
(think building, deleting, shutting-down, ...) the table would highlight
that behavior with 2 changes:
A) the row would be highlighted
B) a barber-pole would show up in the status column

The new-ish registry-based hz-resource-table wasn't making either of
those visual changes.  But now it is!  Hurray for fewer regressions!

Change-Id: Ic84b1eabc2c32e7ba48bf9ce2279f69a4e9a95e0
Partially-Implements: blueprint angular-registry
Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson tyr@hpe.com

Change-Id: Ic84b1eabc2c32e7ba48bf9ce2279f69a4e9a95e0

"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-07-25 19:41:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/d4299ed0a079d94c420b9a31f1ce66050c044725', 'message': "hz-resource-table handles transitional states

In the django tables, if a resource goes into a transitional-state
(think building, deleting, shutting-down, ...) the table would highlight
that behavior with 2 changes:
A) the row would be highlighted
B) a barber-pole would show up in the status column

The new-ish registry-based hz-resource-table wasn't making either of
those visual changes.  But now it is!  Hurray for fewer regressions!

Change-Id: Ic84b1eabc2c32e7ba48bf9ce2279f69a4e9a95e0

commit_message:
hz-resource-table handles transitional states

In the django tables, if a resource goes into a transitional-state
(think building, deleting, shutting-down, ...) the table would highlight
that behavior with 2 changes:
A) the row would be highlighted
B) a barber-pole would show up in the status column

The new-ish registry-based hz-resource-table wasn't making either of
those visual changes.  But now it is!  Hurray for fewer regressions!

Change-Id: Ic84b1eabc2c32e7ba48bf9ce2279f69a4e9a95e0
Partially-Implements: blueprint angular-registry
Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson tyr@hpe.com
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/74/346174/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: row-in-transition-handler="ctrl.rowInTransition"

subject: Add Angular Schema Form
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-22 10:53:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/0b07666001ed3ee3db130ee8c1120263f9f08760', 'message': "[WIP] Add Angular Schema Form and Create Net Workflow

This patch adds Angular Schema Form[1] and its requirements to Horizon,
as well as a solid example via the Create Net Workflow (added to the
Angular Launch Instance Workflow). There are a number of advantages to
this over the current methods of defining forms and workflows :

- All fields have an individual template, making theming improvements,
  bug fixes, and bootstrap conformity easier.
- The file and line count, especially for workflows, is dramatically
  reduced. The Create Net workflow, for example, goes from 12+ files to
  2, with a big reduction in boilerplate HTML.
- All field validation messages are standardised, so we can match them
  across Horizon and plugins

What this patch contains:
- Many common form fields, including things like the themable checkboxes
  and selects.
- A basic modal template that can be passed with ui-bootstraps $modal
  service to take advantage of schema-form
- An improvement to the Create Net workflow, and the ability to launch
  it from the Launch Instance workflow Network step.

Next steps:
- Remove the other modal templates so we can standardise. A single
  template opened from te $modal service is fine, and we shouldn't need
  several directives. In this case, we should deprecate them, as the
  modal forms will be used elsewhere.
- Map commonly used form items, like transfer tables, to a schema form
  type like array (they serve similar purposes, so maybe thats what
  should be replaced)
- Use themable selects instead of regular ones

1. http://schemaform.io/

Change-Id: Ib22b2d0db2c4d4775fdef62a180cc994e8ae6280

  reduced. The Create Net workflow, for example, goes from 12+ files to
  2, with a big reduction in boilerplate HTML.
- All field validation messages are standardised, so we can match them
  across Horizon and plugins

What this patch contains:
- Many common form fields, including things like the themable checkboxes
  and selects.
- A basic modal template that can be passed with ui-bootstraps $modal
  service to take advantage of schema-form
- An improvement to the Create Net workflow, and the ability to launch
  it from the Launch Instance workflow Network step.

Next steps:
- Remove the other modal templates so we can standardise. A single
  template opened from the $modal service is fine, and we shouldn't need
  several directives. In this case, we should deprecate them, as the
  modal forms will be used elsewhere.
- Map commonly used form items, like transfer tables, to a schema form
  type like array (they serve similar purposes, so maybe thats what
  should be replaced)
- Use themable selects instead of regular ones

1. http://schemaform.io/

Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson <tyr@hpe.com>
Change-Id: Ib22b2d0db2c4d4775fdef62a180cc994e8ae6280

commit_message:
Add Angular Schema Form

This patch adds Angular Schema Form[1] and its requirements to Horizon.
There are a number of advantages to this over the current methods of
defining forms and workflows:

- All fields have an individual template, making theming improvements,
  bug fixes, and bootstrap conformity easier.
- The file and line count, especially for workflows, is dramatically
  reduced. The Create Net workflow, for example, goes from 12+ files to
  2, with a big reduction in boilerplate HTML.
- All field validation messages are standardised, so we can match them
  across Horizon and plugins

What this patch contains:
- Many common form fields, including things like the themable checkboxes
  and selects.
- A basic modal template that can be passed with ui-bootstraps $modal
  service to take advantage of schema-form

Next steps:
- Remove the other modal templates so we can standardise. A single
  template opened from the $modal service is fine, and we shouldn't need
  several directives. In this case, we should deprecate them, as the
  modal forms will be used elsewhere.
- Map commonly used form items, like transfer tables, to a schema form
  type like array (they serve similar purposes, so maybe thats what
  should be replaced)
- Use themable selects instead of regular ones

1. http://schemaform.io/

Co-Authored-By: Tyr Johanson <tyr@hpe.com>
Implements: blueprint angular-schema-form
Change-Id: Ib22b2d0db2c4d4775fdef62a180cc994e8ae6280
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/45/332745/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :not(.form-inline) .form-group .themable-select {}

subject: Make 'switch' between legacy and Angular Images
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-07 16:40:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/cdced5f750c3c50ca6e96c6d8682920a0ee02d64', 'message': "Make 'switch' between legacy and Angular Images

This patch follows on the example that the Containers set, providing
a 'switch' in the panel-enablement file that currently defaults to
'legacy' (Python-based Images panel) and allows for 'angular' (Angular-
based Images panel).

To be clear, this does NOT enable Angular Images.  It's just setting the
stage to do so at some point, or to allow deployers/devs to easily switch
between the two.

Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-images-table

commit_message:
Make 'switch' between legacy and Angular Images

This patch follows on the example that the Containers set, providing
a 'switch' in the panel-enablement file that currently defaults to
'legacy' (Python-based Images panel) and allows for 'angular' (Angular-
based Images panel).

To be clear, this does NOT enable Angular Images.  It's just setting the
stage to do so at some point, or to allow deployers/devs to easily switch
between the two.

A switch both for HORIZON_CONFIG and for integration tests is necessary
due to the way integration tests operate.

Co-Authored-By: Timur Sufiev <tsufiev@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I12cd33552218ed1082d2d9a2ae8982639a217a6a
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-images-table

Horizon selects are now themable: DynamicTypedChoiceField

commit_message:
Horizon selects are now themable: Project Panels

Based on Diana's work.
Complete for Admin Panels: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/290204/

Horizon used a standard select input. Unfortunately this type of
input is only customizable to a small extend. Note: not all
ChoiceFields were converted because they have unexpected
impact.

Change-Id: Id9405c6f0127d6e86db09dfaf772f1275a7d7547
Partially-implements: blueprint horizon-theme-css-reorg

subject: Allow listFunction extra params
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-22 23:00:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/72752cb162827640bd8ddd92b5b637459dd395fb', 'message': 'Allow listFunction extra params

Some resource types (like subnets) can only be listed for a given
parent container (like networks). This patch modifies the
hz-resource-table to allow a user to pass in extra paramters that
will be passed to the list function for a given resource type.

For example usage: See DNSaaS
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/341182/9/designatedashboard/static/designatedashboard/resources/os-designate-recordset/details/zone-recordsets.html

For example:
This allows hz-resource-table to be used to show a list of subnets
as one of the details views for a network. The details view
controller passes in the current network ID as an extra paramter
to the hz-resource-table, which in turn, supplies that value to
the subnets list function.  The subnets list function can use
the parameters it is given to build the appropriate API call.

This is very similar to what already exists to pass server search
parameters from magic search to the API in the angular images
table.

Change-Id: I90c851aef0a452e4e8ef39e938ac3ca67a93cfac
Partially-Implements: blueprint angular-registry

commit_message:
Allow listFunction extra params

---
Includes numerous bug fixes to hz-dynamic-table and friends to be
responsive to dynamic table configurations or trackBy expressions.
---

Some resource types (like subnets) can only be listed for a given
parent container (like networks). This patch modifies the
hz-resource-table to allow a user to pass in extra paramters that
will be passed to the list function for a given resource type.

For example usage: See DNSaaS
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/341182/9/designatedashboard/static/designatedashboard/resources/os-designate-recordset/details/zone-recordsets.html

For example:
This allows hz-resource-table to be used to show a list of subnets
as one of the details views for a network. The details view
controller passes in the current network ID as an extra paramter
to the hz-resource-table, which in turn, supplies that value to
the subnets list function.  The subnets list function can use
the parameters it is given to build the appropriate API call.

This is very similar to what already exists to pass server search
parameters from magic search to the API in the angular images
table.

Change-Id: I90c851aef0a452e4e8ef39e938ac3ca67a93cfac
Partially-Implements: blueprint angular-registry
Closes-Bug: 1608462

commit_message:
Stop memoizing on request argument in neutron api

neutron api should memoize more persistanly on objects that do not
change when rendering each view, i.e. Supported extensions list

Implements blueprint: improve-horizon-caching

Change-Id: Iec38e865a704752309ba7035d19370dc0dbc31e0

commit_message:
Move get_filters to parent Class

For server side filtering the method get_filters() is used in every
view, moving this method to the parent class will allow us to not
add it to each view.

Implements blueprint: server-side-filtering

Change-Id: Idaee431ed15de81e5ea049948b55d1526e2024ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/76/341776/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_filters(self, filters=None, map=None): import pdb pdb.set_trace() filters = filters or {} map = map or {} filter_action = self.table._meta._filter_action if filter_action: filter_field = self.table.get_filter_field() if filter_action.is_api_filter(filter_field): filter_string = self.table.get_filter_string().strip() if filter_field and filter_string: if filter_field in map: fil_map = map.get(filter_field) filters[filter_field] = fil_map.get( filter_string.lower()) else: filters[filter_field] = filter_string return filters

commit_message:
Draggable Network Lists should inherit from theme

The network list in the legacy launch instance was not
inheriting from the theme properly.

Change-Id: I02a18adfcad74870f634b363718c77a31efe86fd
Partially-implements: blueprint horizon-theme-css-reorg

commit_message:
Angular Users Panel - REST API update to update password

This is a settings-dependent feature on the Change Password form
to implemented in the future.
It would be enabled in the local_settings.py:
REST_API_REQUIRED_SETTINGS = ['ENFORCE_PASSWORD_CHECK']

This patch adds the additional case to check for Admin Password
if it's available in the request. Inline with the current Django
form behavior.

Change-Id: Ida1cd2fa7aedd8e077829586781026e15130b7ad
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-identity-tables
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/50/210050/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_user_patch_password_with_admin_password_enabled(self, kc): request = self.mock_rest_request(body=''' {"password": "sekrit", "admin_password": "passw0rd"} ''') user = keystone.User() kc.user_get = mock.MagicMock(return_value=user) response = user.patch(request, 'user123') self.assertStatusCode(response, 204) self.assertEqual(response.content, '') kc.user_verify_admin_password.assert_called_once_with(request, 'passw0rd') kc.user_update_password.assert_called_once_with(request, user, 'sekrit') @mock.patch.object(keystone.api, 'keystone')

commit_message:
Implementing RBAC in Identity

Get projects/tenants in Keystone v2 is an operation that can be peformed in the
admin endpoint and in non-admin endpoint.
In this patch I propose to remove the restriction to list projects only
for admin user, and provide this functionality to non-admin users.

blueprint identity-rbac

Change-Id: Ibbf918196f443f360f432bf9aaeb838df9c06331

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-24 15:43:59.000000000', 'files': ['horizon/tables/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/65ba315c23a08edbca3fa3c384ee8c245ea696f0', 'message': 'Added option for cell_attributes_getter to return row data

* if cell_attributes_getter called by a function,
  it now returns the entire row data
* cell_attributes_getter can still receive a dictionary of styles

Implements blueprint: add-option-for-cell-to-access-row-data

Change-Id: I1febeabce4af50cc89929ea600d718e6e168fb33
'}]
commit_message:
Added option for cell_attributes_getter to return row data

* if cell_attributes_getter called by a function,
  it now returns the entire row data
* cell_attributes_getter can still receive a dictionary of styles

Implements blueprint: add-option-for-cell-to-access-row-data

Change-Id: I1febeabce4af50cc89929ea600d718e6e168fb33
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/71/271771/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cag = column.cell_attributes_getter if cag: if (hasattr(cag, 'func_code') and hasattr(cag.func_code, 'co_varnames') and len(cag.func_code.co_varnames) > 0): # returns the entire row data if called by a function cell_attributes = cag(datum) or {} else: cell_attributes = cag(data) or {}

commit_message:
Added test check Instance Overview page

Test check that information on all tabs of instance overview page is
present and correct.

Change-Id: Ie545b28c9dba631a405e34002aaad217542d499b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/34/280134/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from openstack_dashboard.test.integration_tests import helpers from openstack_dashboard.test.integration_tests.regions import messages class TestInstanceOverview(helpers.TestCase): # INSTANCE_NAME = helpers.gen_random_resource_name( # 'instance', timestamp=False) INSTANCE_NAME = "horizon_instance_74259f1b8a9f4015aacfd71b354ba2ce" # def setUp(self): # super(TestInstanceOverview, self).setUp() # self.instances_page = self.home_pg.go_to_compute_instancespage() # self.instances_page.create_instance(self.INSTANCE_NAME) # self.instances_page.find_message_and_dismiss(messages.SUCCESS) # self.assertTrue( # self.instances_page.is_instance_active(self.INSTANCE_NAME)) def test_instance_overview(self): """This test checks edit instance action Steps: 1) Login to Horizon dashboard as regular user 2) Go to Project > Compute > Instances page 3) Create 1 instance. Wait until instance got Active status. 4) Create security group 5) Click dropdown menu in Instance`s row > select Edit Instance menu item 6) Enter another name in appeared Edit instance form 7) Select 'Security Groups' tab, remove current security group and select created on step 4 security group 8) Press Save button > check that Instance name and security group are modified 9) Delete created security group 10) Delete instance from Project > Compute > Instances page """ self.instances_page = self.home_pg.go_to_compute_instancespage() instance_info = self.instances_page.get_instance_info( self.INSTANCE_NAME) overview = self.instances_page.go_to_instance_overview( self.INSTANCE_NAME) self.assertTrue(overview.check_overview_info(instance_info)) # self.assertTrue( # overview.is_security_group_correct(self.SECURITYGROUP_NAME)) # self.assertFalse( # overview.is_security_group_correct('default')) # # instances_page = self.home_pg.go_to_compute_instancespage() # instances_page.edit_instance( # self.INSTANCE_NAME, security_groups=True) # instances_page.find_message_and_dismiss(messages.SUCCESS) # def tearDown(self): # self.instances_page = self.home_pg.go_to_compute_instancespage() # self.instances_page.delete_instance(self.INSTANCE_NAME) # self.instances_page.find_message_and_dismiss(messages.SUCCESS) # self.assertTrue( # self.instances_page.is_instance_deleted(self.INSTANCE_NAME)) # super(TestInstanceOverview, self).tearDown()

commit_message:
Display event stream in the instance audit tab

This feature shows events generated in by the compute actions on the
selected instance. In the admin's instance audit tab, all the events
of an instance will be display. The events show the event type, the
message, the timestamp and the host.

Depends-On: Iadfd0aab28f4d33438bcc9ee5af84fe4c7bdf0a7
Implements: blueprint instance-events
Change-Id: Iccded73c4692dd3e468bf3a0bedbd7f7ede1a22d

Adds a new config value OPENSTACK_SOURCE_BOOT to configure
which sources are available when launching an instance.
Adds tests to check if the expected fields are there.
Provides an error if no boot sources are enabled.
Prevents doing extra calls if a boot source is disabled.

commit_message:
Configuration of boot sources for launch instance

Adds a new configs to LAUNCH_INSTANCE_DEFAULTS to configure
which sources are available when launching an instance.
Adds tests to check if the expected fields are there.
Provides an error if no boot sources are enabled.
Prevents doing extra calls if a boot source is disabled.

Change-Id: I1c970b4c9cdab6341b0dcb5e984b22b342374e08
Implements: blueprint configurable-boot-sources
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/81/259981/32 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Enable or disable the different boot sources that will appear # on the launch instance form OPENSTACK_SOURCE_BOOT = { 'enable_image': True, 'enable_snapshot': True, 'enable_volume': True, }

Implement admin_filter setting in Project>vpn

project>vpn View

Implements blueprint: admin-views-filter-first
Depends-On: Ie752199a38a91969f9501037708372df3a154b53

commit_message:
Remove hostname from the url

The URLs in horizon.conf include the hostname and
all URLs have to be changed when testing a different
openstack host.
Only openstack_host should be changed and urls keep
as is after this patch applys

Closes-Bug: #1429875
Partially implements blueprint: selenium-integration-testing

Change-Id: If8d49a4166d401b3b3a26da7e5d09243ca60b641
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/46/162646/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # self.login_url = self.conf.dashboard.login_url self.login_url = "http://%s%s" % (self.conf.dashboard.OPENSTACK_HOST, self.conf.dashboard.login_url)

commit_message:
Support is_authenticated() and is_anonymous() 1.10

See
https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/releases/1.10/#using-user-is-authenticated-and-user-is-anonymous-as-methods

is_anonymous() and is_authenticated() functions are now properties, and
throw critical security warnings when using python manage.py check in
django 1.10

The duplication is just to make it explicit which code paths are being
followed. They could be refactored to remove it, but in a few months
when we move to the next LTS we would just end up removing the refactors
since there would once again be a single path.

Implements: blueprint dj110

commit_message:
Update the docs to remove run_tests references

This patch removes all references to run_tests.sh, and replaces them
with their tox equivalent. Where necessary, language around the tox
commands has been altered or extended so that it makes sense and is
consistent with other parts of the docs. Also adds a new "Test Environment"
list to the docs, so that newcomers do not have to piece together CLI
commands and their cryptic extensions from tox.ini

Follow up: Merge testing.rst with with topics/testing.rst

Change-Id: If8469d74cc6421ca2315f5eecb6536515e5782eb
Implements: blueprint enhance-tox

added_lines: dashboard structure for you. Run the following commands in your Horizon root directory. It generates most of the boilerplate code you need:: $ mkdir openstack_dashboard/dashboards/mydashboard $ tox -e manage -- startdash mydashboard \ --target openstack_dashboard/dashboards/mydashboard $ mkdir openstack_dashboard/dashboards/mydashboard/mypanel $ tox -e manage -- startpanel mypanel \ --dashboard=openstack_dashboard.dashboards.mydashboard \ --target=openstack_dashboard/dashboards/mydashboard/mypanel $ tox -e runserver -- 0:9000 Go to ``http://<your server>:9000`` using a browser. After login as an admin
deleted_lines: dashboard structure for you. Run the following commands at the same location where the ``run_tests.sh`` file resides. It generates most of the boilerplate code you need:: mkdir openstack_dashboard/dashboards/mydashboard ./run_tests.sh -m startdash mydashboard \ --target openstack_dashboard/dashboards/mydashboard mkdir openstack_dashboard/dashboards/mydashboard/mypanel ./run_tests.sh -m startpanel mypanel \ --dashboard=openstack_dashboard.dashboards.mydashboard \ --target=openstack_dashboard/dashboards/mydashboard/mypanel ./run_tests.sh --runserver 0.0.0.0:8877 Go to ``http://<your server>:8877`` using a browser. After login as an admin

subject: Angular-mock: mock $window object
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-16 22:23:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/4e29d40e38fbed40d8080cbb6361aaa57b4c95da', 'message': 'Angular-mock: mock $window object

This patch provides a shared mock object for $window/window.

window is a native object, not javascript object, and $window
is a wrapper for it. when changing property or invake methods
on it will cause the test runner environment change. And because
it is native, Jasmine cannot spy on those native methods. This
mock resolve the problems.

This mock is available to all the spec files via a very augular
way.

This patch also try to establish a structured approach to
write mock objects:

* mocks should reside in ``.mock.js`` files and be loaded only
  in test runner pages.
* mocks should be loaded after production code files, and before
  spec code files.
* mocks should be sharable between specs.
* mocks should not belong to specs, they should have a 1:1 relationship
  with the object it try to mock.
* mocks should be at a level as low as possible, maybe where JavaScript
  cannot reach directly.
* mocks must be tested theme self.
* mocks should be easy to find, use and manage.

Change-Id: Iec4f1d6a86b967b3320092dc5a16f436a7b96f37

commit_message:
Angular-mock: mock $window object

This patch provides a shared mock object for $window/window.

window is a native object, not javascript object, and $window
is a wrapper for it. when changing property or invake methods
on it will cause the test runner environment change. And because
it is native, Jasmine cannot spy on those native methods. This
mock resolve the problems.

This mock is available to all the spec files via a very augular
way.

This patch also try to establish a structured approach to
write mock objects:

* mocks should reside in ``.mock.js`` files and be loaded only
  in test runner pages.
* mocks should be loaded after production code files, and before
  spec code files.
* mocks should be sharable between specs.
* mocks should not belong to specs, they should have a 1:1 relationship
  with the object it try to mock.
* mocks should be at a level as low as possible, maybe where JavaScript
  cannot reach directly.
* mocks must be tested theme self.
* mocks should be easy to find, use and manage.

Change-Id: Iec4f1d6a86b967b3320092dc5a16f436a7b96f37
Partially-Implements: blueprint horizon-angular-mocks

commit_message:
XStatic Libraries should auto discover

Adding additional XStatic packages to horizon, for ease of
customizability, should be as simple as adding an additional
XStatic package to the requirements.txt file. All new XStatic
libraries, unless configure to server from a special static
path, will automatically be detected and available at
static/horizon/lib/ + package name.

Change-Id: Ice2a8daecde1193405f0eba9534aee254262e4f3
Implements: bp static-file-autodiscovery

commit_message:
Add Angular Project Snapshots Panel

This patch creates a blank Snapshots panel
in the project dashboard.

To be added in subsequent patches:
 - Actions
 - Tables
 - Integration to Searchlight

To test:
It doesn't work with only this one.
You can test volume snapshots panel and table
with "Add Angular Snapshots Table" patch.

Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-volumes-table
Change-Id: I29df92ce7ed9ccbe6ff7fd7d7e4e585d3ba9a6d4

PANEL_GROUP = 'compute' # The slug of the panel to be added to HORIZON_CONFIG. Required. PANEL = 'ngsnapshots' # If set to True, this settings file will not be added to the settings. commit_message:
Add Angular Volumes Table

This patch creates a angular volumes table.

To be added in subsequent patches:
 - Actions
 - Snapshots Table
 - Detail Table
 - Integration to Searchlight

To Test
 - set DISABLED = False in
   _1041_project_ng_volumes_panel.py

Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-volumes-table
Change-Id: I73d614eb84c3b0cafd53144fd6a5ba89c9fa8674

var cinderAPI = { getVolumes: function () { return { data: { items: [ {id: '1', name: 'vol1', size: 1, status: 'available', bootable: false, encrypted: false}, {id: '2', name: 'vol2', size: 2, status: 'available', bootable: true, encrypted: true} ] }, success: function(callback) { callback({items : angular.copy(volumes)}); } }; } }; var userSession = { get: function () { return {project_id: '123'}; } }; var mockQ = { all: function (input) { return { then: function (callback) { callback(input); } }; }, when: function (input, callback) { return callback(input); } }; var expectedVolumes = { 1: {id: '1', name: 'vol1', size: 1, status: 'available', bootable: false, encrypted: false}, 2: {id: '2', name: 'vol2', size: 2, status: 'available', bootable: true, encrypted: true} }; var $scope, controller; beforeEach(module('ui.bootstrap')); beforeEach(module('horizon.framework')); beforeEach(module('horizon.app.core')); beforeEach(module('horizon.app.core.openstack-service-api', function($provide) { $provide.value('horizon.app.core.openstack-service-api.cinder', cinderAPI); controller = $injector.get('$controller'); spyOn(cinderAPI, 'getVolumes').and.callThrough(); spyOn(userSession, 'get').and.callThrough(); spyOn(mockQ, 'all').and.callThrough(); })); function createController() { return controller('horizon.app.core.volumes.table.VolumesController', { cinderAPI: cinderAPI, userSession: userSession, $q: mockQ, $scope: $scope }); } it('should invoke initialization apis', function() { var ctrl = createController(); expect(userSession.get).toHaveBeenCalled(); expect(cinderAPI.getVolumes).toHaveBeenCalled(); expect(ctrl.volumesSrc).toEqual([ expectedVolumes['1'], expectedVolumes['2'] ]); }); }); })();

commit_message:
Add alternative id

Some field has multiple value candidate.

For example, [volume_name] field of Cinder can be set
value of [volume_id] or value of [volume_name].
(if [volume_name] is blank, [volume_is] is set as [volume_name])

Add a 'alt_id' parameter which allow user to set
multiple value candidate.

If [item.id] is blank, [item.alt_id] is set as [item.id].

Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-volumes-table
Change-Id: Icb91438aebae8b715445f8b324be3d4be88bc43c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/89/340189/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: var value = ''; if (column && column.alt_id) { var item = scope.item; var url; value = '{$ (item.' + column.id + '? item.' + column.id + ': item.' + column.alt_id + ') $}'; if (column && column.urlFunction) { url = column.urlFunction(item); } if (url) { value = angular.element('<a>').attr('href',url).append(value)[0].outerHTML; } } html = $compile('<hz-field config="column" item="item">' + value + '</hz-field>')(scope);

commit_message:
Add support for fence_ironic fencing agent.

We can now generate Pacemaker stonith fencing that uses the fence_ironic
fencing agent to control power for failed nodes in an HA deployment.

Partial-Bug: #1649695

Change-Id: I315f9bb78a1296f691dadaeb39fb0a48df1d5f06

List subscribers for a particular service

This commit adds a function to return the subscribers to
a particular service. Used for display in dashboard

added_lines: def get_subscribers(self, service_id): """List of services subscribed to this service.""" result = set() tables = self.subscriptions.get(service_id, None) if not tables: # no subscribers return for t in tables: result = result | self.subscriptions[service_id][t] return list(result)

Add -g parameter with Cmd `total-get`

total-get with -g can get total price of
each tenant and resource

Implements: blueprint price-groupby-fields

Change-Id: I615dd7d674cc83d83b999f33ff3059e44456de8c

commit_message:
Set up pre-defined policy rules automatically in devstack install

In devstack install steps, congress plugin creates policy rules
defined in CONGRESS_PREDEFINED_POLICY_FILE. It enables users to create
thier policy automatically.

Change-Id: I09a08cfd5404e0d123573c0e432dc88c126772e5
Closes-Bug: #1638742
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/53/420653/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # File path to predefined policy and rules CONGRESS_PREDEFINED_POLICY_FILE=${CONGRESS_PREDEFINED_POLICY_FILE:-""}

commit_message:
Adds output_policy_command.py in scripts directory

The script outputs openstack commands that create policy and policy
rules defined in a config file. The config file is formatted in json
style. Sample config file is located at
congress/scripts/preload-policies/policy-rules.json.sample

Change-Id: Ica6bb1bfdc3092a306a890e38ee156ffc71821c0
Partial-Bug: #1638742

commit_message:
Functional test for volume snapshot

Refactor functional tests in volume snapshot.

Change-Id: I2fcc468096b3a26c83b8af1e379a62c80eb9c63e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/94/421194/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
import json # create a volume for all tests to create snapshot cmd_output = json.loads(cls.openstack( 'volume create -f json ' + '--size 1 ' + cls.VOLLY )) cls.wait_for_status('volume show ' + cls.VOLLY, 'available
', 6) cls.VOLUME_ID = cmd_output['id'] raw_output = cls.openstack('volume delete --force ' + cls.VOLLY) cls.assertOutput('', raw_output) def test_volume_snapshot__delete(self): """Test create, delete multiple""" name1 = uuid.uuid4().hex cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot create -f json ' + name1 + ' --volume ' + self.VOLLY )) self.assertEqual( name1, cmd_output["name"], ) name2 = uuid.uuid4().hex cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot create -f json ' + name2 + ' --volume ' + self.VOLLY )) self.assertEqual( name2, cmd_output["name"], ) self.wait_for_status( 'volume snapshot show ' + name1, 'available
', 6) self.wait_for_status( 'volume snapshot show ' + name2, 'available
', 6) del_output = self.openstack( 'volume snapshot delete ' + name1 + ' ' + name2) self.assertOutput('', del_output) def test_volume_snapshot_list(self): """Test create, list filter""" name1 = uuid.uuid4().hex cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot create -f json ' + name1 + ' --volume ' + self.VOLLY )) self.addCleanup(self.openstack, 'volume snapshot delete ' + name1) self.assertEqual( name1, cmd_output["name"], ) self.assertEqual( self.VOLUME_ID, cmd_output["volume_id"], ) self.assertEqual( 1, cmd_output["size"], ) self.wait_for_status( 'volume snapshot show ' + name1, 'available
', 6) name2 = uuid.uuid4().hex cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot create -f json ' + name2 + ' --volume ' + self.VOLLY )) self.addCleanup(self.openstack, 'volume snapshot delete ' + name2) self.assertEqual( name2, cmd_output["name"], ) self.assertEqual( self.VOLUME_ID, cmd_output["volume_id"], ) self.assertEqual( 1, cmd_output["size"], ) self.wait_for_status( 'volume snapshot show ' + name2, 'available
', 6) 'volume snapshot set ' + '--state error ' + name2 ) self.assertOutput('', raw_output) # Test list --long, --status cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot list -f json ' + '--long ' + '--status error' )) names = [x["Name"] for x in cmd_output] self.assertNotIn(name1, names) self.assertIn(name2, names) # Test list --volume cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot list -f json ' + '--volume ' + self.VOLLY )) names = [x["Name"] for x in cmd_output] self.assertIn(name1, names) self.assertIn(name2, names) # Test list --name cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot list -f json ' + '--name ' + name1 )) names = [x["Name"] for x in cmd_output] self.assertIn(name1, names) self.assertNotIn(name2, names) """Test create, set, unset, show, delete volume snapshot""" name = uuid.uuid4().hex new_name = name + "_" cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot create -f json ' + '--volume ' + self.VOLLY + ' --description aaaa ' + '--property Alpha=a ' + name )) self.addCleanup(self.openstack, 'volume snapshot delete ' + new_name) self.assertEqual( name, cmd_output["name"], ) self.assertEqual( 1, cmd_output["size"], ) self.assertEqual( 'aaaa', cmd_output["description"], ) self.assertEqual( "Alpha='a'", cmd_output["properties"], ) self.wait_for_status( 'volume snapshot show ' + name, 'available
', 6) # Test volume snapshot set 'volume snapshot set ' + '--name ' + new_name + ' --description bbbb ' + '--property Alpha=c ' + '--property Beta=b ' + name, ) self.assertOutput('', raw_output) # Show snapshot set result cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot show -f json ' + new_name )) self.assertEqual( new_name, cmd_output["name"], ) self.assertEqual( 1, cmd_output["size"], ) self.assertEqual( 'bbbb', cmd_output["description"], ) self.assertEqual( "Alpha='c', Beta='b'", cmd_output["properties"], ) # Test volume unset raw_output = self.openstack( 'volume snapshot unset ' + '--property Alpha ' + new_name, ) self.assertOutput('', raw_output) cmd_output = json.loads(self.openstack( 'volume snapshot show -f json ' + new_name )) self.assertEqual( "Beta='b'", cmd_output["properties"], )
deleted_lines:
NAME = uuid.uuid4().hex OTHER_NAME = uuid.uuid4().hex HEADERS = ['"Name"'] cls.openstack('volume create --size 1 ' + cls.VOLLY) cls.wait_for_status('volume show ' + cls.VOLLY, 'available
', 3) opts = cls.get_opts(['status']) raw_output = cls.openstack('volume snapshot create --volume ' + cls.VOLLY + ' ' + cls.NAME + opts) cls.assertOutput('creating
', raw_output) cls.wait_for_status( 'volume snapshot show ' + cls.NAME, 'available
', 3) # Rename test raw_output = cls.openstack( 'volume snapshot set --name ' + cls.OTHER_NAME + ' ' + cls.NAME) cls.assertOutput('', raw_output) # Delete test raw_output_snapshot = cls.openstack( 'volume snapshot delete ' + cls.OTHER_NAME) raw_output_volume = cls.openstack('volume delete --force ' + cls.VOLLY) cls.assertOutput('', raw_output_snapshot) cls.assertOutput('', raw_output_volume) def test_snapshot_list(self): opts = self.get_opts(self.HEADERS) raw_output = self.openstack('volume snapshot list' + opts) self.assertIn(self.NAME, raw_output) def test_snapshot_properties(self): 'volume snapshot set --property a=b --property c=d ' + self.NAME) self.assertEqual("", raw_output) opts = self.get_opts(["properties"]) raw_output = self.openstack('volume snapshot show ' + self.NAME + opts) self.assertEqual("a='b', c='d'
", raw_output) raw_output = self.openstack( 'volume snapshot unset --property a ' + self.NAME) self.assertEqual("", raw_output) raw_output = self.openstack('volume snapshot show ' + self.NAME + opts) self.assertEqual("c='d'
", raw_output) 'volume snapshot set --description backup ' + self.NAME) self.assertEqual("", raw_output) opts = self.get_opts(["description", "name"]) raw_output = self.openstack('volume snapshot show ' + self.NAME + opts) self.assertEqual("backup
" + self.NAME + "
", raw_output)

commit_message:
Remove store events setting

store_events is removed upstream from ceilometer.
Use event_dispatcher instead to redirect events.

Change-Id: I425a8093046574a2e0b24a6fe64691b247189716
Closes-Bug: #1657555

commit_message:
Treat invalid limit parameters as errors

GET method to list containers or objects with the invalid
"limit" parameter such as "?limit=no_integer" is expected
to return 400. Currently, it returns 200 because an invalid
parameter is not reported but ignored.

This patchset will fix this.
Now invalid limit parameter value will report 400.

Change-Id: Ia5d799d88caf23a61235926186b01c4e9a0e9f17
Closes-Bug:#1254638

commit_message:
conf: Remove 'virt' file

We have "compute" options and "virt" options but there isn't really a
difference between the two. Move two to "network" and the remainder to
"compute", allowing us to drop "virt".

There are no actual changes to the opts, besides a typo fix for the
'reserved_huge_pages' opt.

Change-Id: Ibe7ba5716c6bfb096aabb85c73e5167f337a7327
Implements: blueprint centralize-config-options-ocata

commit_message:
Restrict enabling the manage_snapshot volume feature

The test that is in tempest for this feature is
specific to LVM and will *not* work for other backends
regardless of them supporting the feature. It shouldn't
default to enabled for everyone, only for LVM.

If others want to opt-in they can, but its definitely
the minority that would.

Change-Id: I21347f2a5069059e6413208b254d5acd246faaea

commit_message:
Move db migration tests to functional tests

They were initally added to unit tests as the functional tests were
non-voting, see:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/388599/

Now that functional tests are voting, we can move the db migration tests
where they belong, and relax the OS_FAIL_ON_MISSING_DEPS setting on unit
tests

Change-Id: I90f39d4209188f2ca744f12d573d4854844a19fc

commit_message:
conf: move few console opts to xenserver group

console_allowed_origins and console_public_hostname are specific
to XenServer deployments, so moving them to xenserver group.
Leaving the rest as they are or will be deprecated.

Implements: bp centralize-config-options-ocata
Co-Authored-By: Sarafraj Singh <sarafraj.singh@intel.com>

Change-Id: I154f18ab2943465db5e3e9fcee06f2a7269df898

commit_message:
Adding info on syntribos and a trivial change

- Adding info on syntribos to the section on security tools
- Rearranging sections for Bandit and Anchor in the
alphabetical order.

Change-Id: Ia68a02dffe95c4f22bd48fa5e84d00b8dba53ed1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ossa refs/changes/10/418610/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Anchor - ephemeral PKI ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Anchor is a lightweight, open source, Public Key Infrastructure (PKI), which uses automated provisioning of short-term certificates to enable cryptographic trust in OpenStack services. Certificates are typically valid for 12-24 hours and are issued based on the result from a policy enforcing decision engine. Short term certificates enable passive revocation, to bypass the issues with the traditional revocation mechanisms used in most PKI deployments. * `Anchor Git Repository <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/anchor>`_ * `Anchor Gerrit <https://review.openstack.org/#/q/anchor,n,z>`_ * `Anchor Launchpad <https://bugs.launchpad.net/anchor>`_ Syntribos - Python API security testing tool ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Syntribos is an open source automated API security testing tool that is maintained by members of the `OpenStack Security Project <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security>`_. Given a simple configuration file and an example HTTP request, syntribos can replace any API URL, URL parameter, HTTP header and request body field with a given set of strings. Syntribos iterates through each position in the request automatically. The tool aims to automatically detect common security defects such as SQL injection, LDAP injection, buffer overflow, etc. In addition, it can be used to help identify new security defects by automated fuzzing. Syntribos can be installed directly from `pypi with pip <https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip>`_. * `Syntribos developer documentation <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/syntribos/>`_ * `Syntribos Git Repository <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/syntribos>`_ * `Syntribos Gerrit <https://review.openstack.org/#/q/syntribos,n,z>`_ * `Syntribos Launchpad <https://bugs.launchpad.net/syntribos>`_
deleted_lines: Anchor - ephemeral PKI ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Anchor is a lightweight, open source, Public Key Infrastructure (PKI), which uses automated provisioning of short-term certificates to enable cryptographic trust in OpenStack services. Certificates are typically valid for 12-24 hours and are issued based on the result from a policy enforcing decision engine. Short term certificates enable passive revocation, to bypass the issues with the traditional revocation mechanisms used in most PKI deployments. * `Anchor Git Repository <https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/anchor>`_ * `Anchor Gerrit <https://review.openstack.org/#/q/anchor,n,z>`_ * `Anchor Launchpad <https://bugs.launchpad.net/anchor>`_

commit_message:
conf: Deprecate yet more nova-net options

These things are everywhere.

Floating IP, fixed IP and security group quotas are only applicable when
using nova-net as neutron takes care of quotas itself [1]. This means
these features, like nova-net itself, can be deprecated.

http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide/cli-networking-advanced-quotas.html

Change-Id: If66ad25e52374733be19fe4d39cd34c5c627c69a
Implements: bp centralize-config-options-ocata

commit_message:
conf: Resolve formatting issues with 'quota'

There were a couple of issues with this file:

- Inconsistent use of "Summary-Detail"-style formatting
- Unnecessary use of "Possible values" sections
- Inconsistent indentation

Resolve all of the above.

Change-Id: I7b0e7f9dc903f1a5078c2d67feb72037500dfd9e
Implements: bp centralize-config-options-ocata
